ygData.msgSnippet: Hi I found this page about scale-free networks too, a good reading :) I am sorry, my previous answer lacks some precision, here it is a more precise one *

Hi

  I found this page about scale-free networks too, a
good reading :) I'am sorry, my previous answer lacks
some precision, here it is a more precise one
 * population size : 500
 * elitism per species : 2
 * reproduction ratio : 0.8

For one individual
 * crossover probability : 0.1 
 * edge-weight-perturb mutation probability : 0.8
 * add-edge mutation probability : 0.05
 * add-node probability : 0.04
 * unactivated edge activation : 0.01

And of course : 0.8 + 0.05 + 0.04 + 0.01 + 0.1 = 1.0

So when I pick an individual to apply a add-edge or a
add-node mutation, I just add one node, or add one
edge. The candidate node/edge is selected with an
uniform probability in the set of the nodes/edges that
don't violate the topologic constraints fixed by the
user (like a "no cycle" constraints), after mutation. 

So my implementation works as you in your suggestion.

--- Sandor Murakozi <smurakozi@...> a �crit :

> Hi Alex,
> 
> I have a guess why your implementation likes to
> create scale-free networks.
> 
> I just checked the wikipedia page for scale-free
> networks, and found this
> section interesting:
> 
> "...The mostly widely known generative model for a
> subset of scale-free
> networks is Barab�si and Albert's (1999) *rich get
> richer* generative model
> in which each new Web page creates links to existent
> Web pages with a
> probability distribution which is not uniform, but
> proportional to the
> current in-degree of Web pages. This model was
> originally discovered by Derek
> J. de Solla Price
>
<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Derek_J._de_Solla_Price>
> in
> 1965 under the term *cumulative advantage*, but did
> not reach popularity
> until Barab�si rediscovered the results under its
> current name (BA
> Model<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/BA_Model>).
> According to this process, a page with many in-links
> will attract more
> in-links than a regular page...".
> 
> If your splitting operation is applied on each
> connections with equal
> probability, then you will have exactly this
> phenomenon: nodes which already
> have a bit more connections will have a greater
> prob. to get even more.
> 
> E.g. say you have some nodes and pick 2 of them. The
> first have 2
> connections (1 incoming and 1 outgoing), while the
> other has 4. Now if you
> have a 0.04 probability of splitting for each
> connection, then the first one
> will have about 0.08 prob. to get a new connection,
> while the other one will
> have about 0.16, so it will be quite likely that
> this node will grow
> connections faster (and faster).
> 
> Result: nodes already having a bit more connections
> will have even more and
> you will get a scale free network quite soon.
> 
> If you really have this situation then it is quite
> easy to avoid it: apply
> the split mutation on the network with X
> probability, and in case of
> mutation just pick one random connection.
> 
> Hope this will help you to solve your problem.
> 
> Cheers,
> don
> 
> On 1/4/07, Alex <marmakoide@...> wrote:
> >
> >   I use my own implementation of NEAT integrated
> the Open Beagle
> > framework. I don't use the stolen babies
> mechanism.
> >
> > * population size : 500
> > * elitism per species : 2
> > * crossover probability : 0.1
> > * edge mutation probability : 0.8
> > * add-edge probability : 0.05
> > * add-edge probability : 0.04
> > * unactivated edge activation probability : 0.01
> > * reproduction ratio : 0.8
> >
> > A bias to the scale-free networks is good if they
> are good solutions,
> > but in the general case (no idea about the
> solution), I don't like
> > that much...
> >
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com
> <neat%40yahoogroups.com>, "Kenneth Stanley"
> > <kstanley@...> wrote:
> > >
> > > I don't believe I've heard this observation
> before. It could be
> > > interesting to those studying the benefits of
> scale-free networks.
> > > What are the particular parameters that yield
> this bias to scale-
> > > free networks?
> > >
> > > ken
> > >
> > > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com
> <neat%40yahoogroups.com>, "Alex"
> > <marmakoide@> wrote:
> > > >
> > > > Hi all
> > > >
> > > > I made some runs with Neat to evolve recurrent
> neural networks.
> > > By
> > > > playing with the structural mutation
> (add-node, add-edge, etc...)
> > > > probabilities, I saw a bias for particular
> network topologies. As
> > > > instance, I found a setting that provide
> scale-free networks. I saw
> > > > this bias with both a real life fitness
> measure and a dummy one
> > > > (returns the generation of the individual).
> > > >
> > > > Did somebody notices that ? Is it a good or a
> bad news ?
> > > >
> > >
> >
> >  
> >
>
